verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:8
verses.text: Bishop Bull has suggested a very ingenious interpretation of it, which is not obvious, but which, when stated, has much plausibility, as going to explain, or rather to sanction, certain modes of speech in some early Fathers of venerable authority, which have been urged by heterodox writers, and given up by Catholics of the Roman School, as savouring of Arianism.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:9
verses.text: The foregoing pages have made it abundantly evident that the point of controversy between Catholics and Arians was, not whether our Lord was God, but whether He was Son of God; the solution of the former question being involved in that of the latter.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:10
verses.text: The Arians maintained that the very word 'Son' implied a 'beginning,' or that our Lord was not Very God; the Catholics said that it implied 'connaturality,' or that He was Very God as one with God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:11
verses.text: Now five early writers, Athenagoras, Tatian, Theophilus, Hippolytus, and Novatian, of whom the authority of Hippolytus is very great, not to speak of Theophilus and Athenagoras, whatever be thought of Tatian and of Novatian, seem to speak of the divine generation as taking place immediately before the creation of the world, that is, as if not eternal, though at the same time they teach that our Lord existed before that generation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:12
verses.text: In other words they seem to teach that He was the Word from eternity, and became the Son at the beginning of all things; some of them expressly considering Him, first as the λόγος ἐνδιάθετος, or Reason, in the Father, or (as may be speciously represented) a mere attribute; next, as the λόγος προφορικὸς, or Word, terms which are explained, note on de Syn.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:13
verses.text: This doctrine, when divested of figure and put into literal statement, might appear nothing more or less than this,—that at the beginning of the world the Son was created after the likeness of the Divine attribute of Reason, as its image or expression, and thereby became the Divine Word, was made the instrument of creation, called the Son from that ineffable favour and adoption which God had bestowed on Him, and in due time sent into the world to manifest God's perfections to mankind;—which, it is scarcely necessary to say, is the doctrine of Arianism.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:14
verses.text: Thus S.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:33
verses.text: And then he adds (which is our present point), that it is even alluded to and recognised in the Creed of the Council, which anathematizes those who say that 'the Son was not before His generation,' i-e: who deny that 'the Son was before His generation,' which statement accordingly becomes indirectly a Catholic truth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:34
verses.text: I am not aware whether any writer has preceded or followed this great authority in this view.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:35
verses.text: The more obvious mode of understanding the Arian formula is this, that it is an argument ex absurdo, drawn from the force of the word Son, in behalf of the Arian doctrine; it being, as they would say, a truism, that, 'whereas He was begotten, He was not before He was begotten,' and the denial of it a contradiction in terms.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:36
verses.text: This certainly does seem to myself the true force of the formula; so much so, that if Bishop Bull's explanation be admissible, it must, in order to its being so, first be shewn to be reducible to this sense, and to be included under it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:37
verses.text: The point at issue between the two interpretations is this; whether the clause πρὶν γεννηθῆναι οὐκ ἦν is intended for a denial of the contrary proposition, 'He was before His generation,' as Bishop Bull says; or whether it is what Aristotle calls an enthymematic sentence, assuming the falsity, as confessed on all hands, of that contrary proposition, as self-contradictory, and directly denying, not it, but 'He was from everlasting.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:38
verses.text: ' Or, in other words, whether it opposes the position of the five writers, or the great Catholic doctrine itself; and whether in consequence the Nicene Fathers are in their anathema indirectly sanctioning that position, or stating that doctrine.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:39
verses.text: Bull considers that both sides contemplated the proposition, 'He was before His generation,'—and that the Catholics asserted or defended it; some reasons shall here be given for the contrary view.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:40
verses.text: Now first, let me repeat, what was just now observed by the way, that the formula in question, when taken as an enthymematic sentence, or reductio ad absurdum, exactly expresses the main argument of the Arians, which they brought forward in so many shapes, as feeling that their cause turned upon it, 'He is a son, therefore He had a beginning.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:41
verses.text: ' Thus Socrates records Arius's words in the beginning of the controversy,  'If the Father begat the Son, He who is begotten has a beginning of existence;  therefore once the Son was not, ἦν ὅτε οὐκ ἦν;  therefore He has His subsistence from nothing, ἐξ οὐκ ὄντων ἔχει τὴν ὑπόστασιν.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:42
Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:43

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:45
verses.text: The first of these propositions exactly answers to the οὐκ ἦν πρὶν γεννηθῆναι taken enthymematically; and it may be added that when so taken, the three propositions will just answer to the three first formulae anathematized at Nicaea, two of which are indisputably the same as two of them; viz.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:46
verses.text: ὅτι ἦν ποτὲ δτε οὐκ ἦν· & ·τι πρὶν γεννηθῆναι οὐκ ἦν· & ·τι ἐξ οὐκ ὄντων ἐγένετο.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:47
verses.text: On the other hand, we hear nothing in the controversy of the position which Bull conceives to be opposed by Arius ('He was before His generation'), that is, supposing the formula in question does not allude to it; unless indeed it is worth while to except the statement reprobated in the Letter of the Arians to Alexander, ὄντα πρότερον, γεννηθέντα εἰς υἱ& ·ν, which is explained, de Syn.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:49
verses.text: Next, it should be observed that the other formulae here, as elsewhere, mentioned, are enthymematic also, or carry their argument with them, and that, an argument resolvable often into the original argument derived from the word 'Son.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:50
verses.text: ' Such are ὁ ὢν τὸν μὴ ὄντα ἐκ τοῦ ὄντος ἢ τὸν ὄντα; and ἓν τὸ ἀγένητον ἢ δύο; and in like manner as regards the question of the τρεπτόν; 'Has He free will' (thus Athanasius states the Arian objection) 'or has He not? is He good from choice according to free will, and can He, if He will, alter, being of an alterable nature? as wood or stone, has He not His choice free to be moved, and incline hither and thither?' supr.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:51
Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:52
verses.text: That is, they wished the word τρεπτὸς to carry with it its own self-evident application to our Lord, with the alternative of an absurdity; and so to prove His created nature.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:54
verses.text: Athanasius observes that the formula of the ἀγένητον was the later substitute for the original formulae of Arius; 'when they were no longer allowed to say, "out of nothing," and "He was not before His generation,"' they hit upon this word Unoriginate, that, by saying among the simple that the Son was originate, they might imply the very same phrases "out of nothing" and "He once was not".

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:55
verses.text: Here he does not in so many words say that the argument from the ἀγένητον was a substitute for the οὐκ ἦν πρὶν γεννηθῆναι, yet surely it is not unfair so to understand him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:56
verses.text: But it is plain that the ἀγένητον was brought forward merely to express by an appeal to philosophy and earlier Fathers, that to be a Son was to have a beginning and a creation, and not to be God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:57
verses.text: This therefore will be the sense of the οὐκ ἦν πρὶν γεννηθῆναι.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:58
verses.text: Nay, when the Arians asked, 'Is the ἀγένητον one or two,' they actually did assume that it was granted by their opponents that the Father only was ἀγένητος; which it was not, if the latter held, nay, if they had sanctioned at Nicaea, as Bull says, that our Lord ἦν πρὶν γεννηθῇ; and moreover which they knew and confessed was not granted, if their own formula οὐκ ἦν πρὶν γεννηθῆναι was directed against this statement.

verses.text: ,' he does but mean, 'if it can be said,' 'if the words can be used or applied in this case.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:137
verses.text: ' Now the two Fathers just mentioned both decide that it is not true, either that the Son was before His generation, or that He was not; in other words, that the question is unmeaning and irrelevant, which is just the interpretation which has been here given to Athanasius.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:138
verses.text: But again, in thus speaking, they thereby assert also that they did not hold, that they do not allow, that formula which Bull considers the Nicene Fathers defended and sanctioned, as being Catholic and in use both before the Council and after, viz.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:139
verses.text: 'He was before His generation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:140
verses.text: ' Thus S.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:141
verses.text: Gregory in the passage in which he speaks of 'did He that is make Him that is not, &c.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:142
verses.text: ,' and 'before His generation, &c.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:143
verses.text: ,' as one and the same, expressly says, 'In His case, to be begotten is concurrent with existence and is from the beginning,' and that in contrast to the instance of men; who he says, do fulfil in a manner 'He who is, &c.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:144
verses.text: ' (Levi being in the loins of Abraham), i-e: fulfil Bull's proposition, 'He was before generation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:145
verses.text: ' He proceeds, 'I say that the question is irrelevant, not the answer difficult.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:146
verses.text: ' And presently after, mentioning some idle inquiries by way of parallel, he adds, 'more ill-instructed, be sure, is it to decide whether what was generated from the beginning was or was not before generation, πρὸ τῆς γεννήσεως.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:147
verses.text: ' Orat.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:148
verses.text: S.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:149
verses.text: Hilary, on the other hand, is so full on the subject in his de Trin.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:150
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:151
verses.text: , and so entirely to the point for which I would adduce him, that but a few extracts of what might be made are either necessary or practicable.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:152
verses.text: He states and argues on the formula expressly as an objection; Adjiciant haec arguta satis atque auditu placentia; Si, inquit, natus est, coepit; et cum coepit, non fuit; et cum non fuit, non patitur ut fuerit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:153
verses.text: Atque idcirco piae intelligentiae, sermonem esse contendant, Non fuit ante quam nasceretur, quia ut esset, qui non erat, natus est.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:154
Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:155
verses.text: He answers the objection in the same way.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:156
verses.text: 'Unigenitus Deus neque non fuit aliquando non filius, neque fuit aliquid ante quam filius, neque quidquam aliquid ipse nisi filius,' n.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:157
verses.text: , which is in express words to deny, 'He was before His generation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:158
verses.text: ' Again, as Gregory, 'Ubi pater auctor est, ibi et nativitas est; et vero ubi auctor aeternus est, ibi et nativitatis aeternitas est,' n.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:159
verses.text: And he substitutes 'being always born' for 'being before birth;' 'Numquid ante tempora aeterna esse, id ipsum sit quod est, eum qui erat nasci? quia nasci quod erat, jam non nasci est, sed se ipsum demutare nascendo.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:160
verses.text: …Non est itaque id ipsum, natum ante tempora aeterna semper esse, et esse antequam nasci.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:161
Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:162
verses.text: And he concludes, in accordance with the above explanation of the passages of Athanasius which I brought as if objections, thus: 'Cum itaque natum semper esse, nihil aliud sit confitendum esse, quam natum, id sensui, antequam nascitur vel fuisse, vel non fuisse non subjacet.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:163
verses.text: n.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:164
Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:165
verses.text: It may seem superfluous to proceed, but as Bishop Bull is an authority not lightly to be set aside, a passage from S.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:166
verses.text: Basil shall be added.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:167
verses.text: Eunomius objects, 'God begat the Son either being or not being, &c.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:168
verses.text: …to him that is, there needs not generation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:169
verses.text: ' He replies that Eunomius, 'because animals first are not, and then are generated, and he who is born to-day, yesterday did not exist, transfers this conception to the subsistence of the Only-begotten; and says, since He has been generated, He was not before His generation, πρὸ τῆς γεννήσεως,' contr.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:170
verses.text: Eunom.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:171
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:172
verses.text: And he solves the objection as the other Fathers, by saying that our Lord is from everlasting, speaking of S.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:173
verses.text: John, in the first words of his Gospel, as τῇ ἀ& ·διότητι τοῦ πατρὸς τοῦ μονογενοῦς συνάπτων τὴν γέννησιν.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:174
Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:175
verses.text: These then being the explanations which the contemporary and next following Fathers give of the Arian formula which was anathematized at Nicaea, it must be observed that the line of argument which Bishop Bull is pursuing, does not lead him to assign any direct reasons for the substitution of a different interpretation in their place.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:176
verses.text: He is engaged, not in commenting on the Nicene Anathema, but in proving that the Post-Nicene Fathers admitted that view or statement of doctrine which he conceives also implied in that anathema; and thus the sense of the anathema, instead of being the subject of proof, is, as he believes, one of the proofs of the point which he is establishing.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:177
verses.text: However, since these other collateral evidences which he adduces, may be taken to be some sort of indirect comment upon the words of the Anathema, the principal of them in point of authority, and that which most concerns us, shall here be noticed: it is a passage from the second Oration of Athanasius.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:178
verses.text: While commenting on the words, ἀρχὴ ὁδῶν εἰς τὰ ἔργα in the text, 'The Lord has created me the beginning of His ways unto the works,' S.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:179
verses.text: Athanasius is led to consider the text 'first born of every creature,' πρωτότοκος πασῆς κτίσεως: and he says that He who was μονογενὴς from eternity, became by a συγκατάβασις at the creation of the world πρωτότοκος.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:180
verses.text: This doctrine Bp.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:181
verses.text: Bull considers declaratory of a going forth, προέλευσις, or figurative birth from the Father, at the beginning of all things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:182
verses.text: It will be observed that the very point to be proved is this, viz.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:183
verses.text: not that there was a συγκατάβασις merely, but that according to Athanasius there was a γέννησις or proceeding from the Father, and that the word πρωτότοκος marks it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:184
verses.text: Bull's words are, that 'Catholici quidam Doctores, qui post exortam controversiam Arianam vixerunt,…illam τοῦ λόγου.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:185
verses.text: …ex Patre progressionem (quod et συγκατάβασιν, hoc est, condescensionem eorum nonnulli appellarunt), ad condendum haec universa agnovere; atque ejus etiam progressionis respectu ipsum τὸν λόγον a Deo Patre quasi natum fuisse et omnis creaturae primogenitum in Scripturis dici confessi sunt.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:186
Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:187
verses.text: F.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:188
verses.text: N.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:189
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:190
Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:191
verses.text: Now I consider that S.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:192
verses.text: Athanasius does not, as this sentence says, understand by primogenitus that our Lord was 'progressionis respectu a Deo Patre quasi natus.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:193
verses.text: ' He does not seem to me to speak of a generation or birth of the Son at all, though figurative, but of the birth of all things, and that in Him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:194
verses.text: That Athanasius does not call the συγκατάβασις of the Word a birth, as denoted by the term πρωτότοκος, is plain from his own avowal in the passage to which Bull refers.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:195
verses.text: 'Nowhere in the Scriptures,' he says, 'is He called πρωτότοκος τοῦ Θεοῦ, first-born of God, nor creature of God, but Only-begotten, Word, Wisdom, have their relation to the Father, and are proper to Him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:196
verses.text: ' ii.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:197
verses.text: Here surely he expressly denies Bull's statement that 'first-born' means 'a Deo natus,' 'born of God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:198
verses.text: ' Such additions as παρὰ τοῦ πατρὸς, he says, are reserved for μονογενὴς and λόγος.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:199
verses.text: He goes on to say what the term πρωτότοκος does mean; viz.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:200
verses.text: instead of having any reference to a προέλευσις from the Father, it refers solely to the creatures; our Lord is not called πρωτότοκος, because His προέλευσις is a 'type of His eternal generation,' but because by that προέλευσις He became the 'Prototype of all creation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:201
verses.text: ' He, as it were, stamped His image, His Sonship, upon creation, and became the first-born in the sense of being the Archetypal Son.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:202
verses.text: If this is borne out by the passage, Athanasius, it is plain, does not speak of any γέννησις whatever at the era of creation, though figurative; πρωτότοκος does but mean μονογενὴς πρωτεύων ἐν τῇ κτίσει, or ἀρχὴ τῆς κτίσεως, or πρωτότυπον γέννημα, or μόνος γεννητὸς ἐν τοῖς γενητοῖς; and no warrant is given, however indirect, to the idea that in the Nicene Anathema, the Fathers implied an allowance of the proposition, 'He was before His generation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:203
verses.text: '  As the whole passage occurs in the Discourse which immediately follows, it is not necessary to enter formally into the proof of this view of it, when the reader will soon be able to judge of it for himself.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:204
verses.text: But it may be well to add two passages, one from Athenagoras, the other from S.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:205
verses.text: Cyril, not in elucidation of the words of Athanasius, but of the meaning which I would put upon them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:206
verses.text: The passage from Athenagoras is quoted by Bull himself, who of course is far from denying the doctrine of our Lord's Archetypal office; and does but wish in addition to find in Athanasius the doctrine of a γέννησις.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:207
verses.text: Athenagoras says that the Son is 'the first offspring, πρῶτον γέννημα, of the Father, not as come to be, γενόμενον (for God being Eternal Mind had from the beginning in Himself the Word, as having Reason eternally, λογικὸς ὢν), but that while as regards matter heavy and light were mixed together' (the passage is corrupt here), 'He went forth, προελθὼν, as an idea and energy', i-e: as an Agent to create, and a Form and Rule to create by.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:208
verses.text: And then he goes on to quote the very text on which Athanasius is employed when he explains πρωτότοκος.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:209
verses.text: 'And the Prophetic Spirit confirms this doctrine, saying, The Lord hath created me a beginning (origin) of His ways, for His works.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:210
verses.text: ' Leg.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:211
verses.text: And so S.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:212
verses.text: Cyril, 'He is Only-begotten according to nature, as being alone from the Father, God from God, Light kindled from Light; and He is First-born for our sakes, that, as if to some immortal root the whole creation might be ingrafted and might bud forth from the Everlasting.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:213
verses.text: For all things were made by Him, and consist for ever and are preserved in Him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:214
verses.text: ' Thesaur.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:215
verses.text: p.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:216
verses.text: In conclusion it may be suggested whether the same explanation which has here been given of Athanasius's use of πρωτότοκος does not avail more exactly to the defence of two of the five writers from the charge of inaccurate doctrine, than that which Bull has preferred.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:217
verses.text: As to Athenagoras, we have already seen that he does not speak of a γέννησις at all in his account of creation, but simply calls the Son πρῶτον γέννημα, i-e: πρωτότυπον γέννημα.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:218
verses.text: Nor does Tatian approach nearer to the doctrine of a γέννησις.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:219
verses.text: He says that at the creation the Word ἔργον πρωτότοκον τοῦ πατρὸς γίνεται.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:220
verses.text: τοῦτον ἴσμεν τοῦ κόσμου τὴν ἀρχήν.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:221
verses.text: ad Graec.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:222
verses.text: Here the word ἔργον, which at first sight promises a difficulty, does in fact explain both himself and Athenagoras.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:223
verses.text: He says that at creation the Word became, γίνεται, not a Son (figuratively), as Bull would grant to the parties whom he is opposing, but a work.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:224
verses.text: It was His great condescension, συγκατάβασις, to be accounted the first of the works, as being their type; that as they were to be raised to an adoption and called sons, so He for that purpose might stoop to creation, and be called a work.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:225
verses.text: As Tatian uses the word ἀρχὴ in the concluding clause, there is great reason to think that he is alluding to the very text which Athanasius and Athenagoras expressly quote, in which Wisdom is said to be 'created a beginning, ἀρχὴ, of ways, unto the works, εἰς τὰ ἔργα.

verses.name: Athanasius: Against the Arians Excursus B 1:226
verses.text: '  As to Novatian, Bishop Bull himself observes that it is a question whether he need be understood to speak of any generation but that which is eternal; nor does Pamelius otherwise explain him.
